article_title: Latinas in New Orleans applaud healthcare ruling, Mexican artwork on display
article_text:
Hispanic organizations in New Orleans joined others nationwide in applauding the recent ruling of the Supreme Court in King v. Burwell to uphold a key part of the Affordable Care Act, ​​ensuring that people in 34 states will continue to have access to the tax credits that make their health coverage affordable. This decision preserves the financial assistance that has helped more than six million individuals purchase insurance plans through Obamacare's federally-run marketplaces, effectively maintaining affordable access to health care.

Jessica González-Rojas, executive director of the National Latina Institute for Reproductive Health (NLIRH) issued the following statement: "Thanks to this ruling, hundreds of thousands of Latinas will retain their health insurance, and up to two million will retain the opportunity to access affordable coverage, now and in the future. Before the Affordable Care Act, more than 1 in 3 Latinas had no health insurance at all, and millions of others struggled with overpriced coverage and inadequate care. Thanks to the gains of the ACA, more Latinas than ever have access to quality, affordable care, and we will not stop until that promise is fulfilled. Latinas will not go back."

Lilia Fletcher-Moreno is a Certified Navigator in the West Bank and Southeast in Spanish for Southeast Louisiana Area Health Education Center (SELAHEC) who helps the local community to access Obamacare health care insurance plans free of charge.

A native of Panama, Fletcher-Moreno has a master degree in hospital administration from the Universidad Autonoma de Mexico and an undergraduate degree in business administration from Santa Maria La Antigua College in Panama City. She worked for different companies and was an owner business in Panama and Mexico . Fletcher-Moreno has lived and worked in New Orleans since 2007.

To find out more about how to apply for Obamacare assistance, contact Fletcher-Moreno at lilia.fletcher-moreno@selahec.org

Summer business festival set

The Hispanic Chamber of Commerce and Liga Islano will hold a Summer Business Festival July 12 from 1 to 7 p.m. at Pan American Stadium in City Park. Adults admission is $5 and children are admitted free. Food, beverages and music as well as children activities and free community services (legal, health, immigration, insurance and banking) will be featured. For information, call 504.885.4262.

Storytime

A bilingual Spanish/English story time for children ages 4 to 8 will be held July 11 at 1 p.m. at the Pebbles Center at the Children's Resource Center Library, at 913 Napoleon Avenue in the Uptown New Orleans. The story time will be followed by crafts.

Art exhibit

The Consulate of Mexico in New Orleans will present an art installation, "Between Before & After" by Mexican artist Ale de la Puente July 17 at 6 p.m. at the Art Gallery of the Consulate, 901 Convention Center Blvd., Suite 118. An opening reception will be held July 17 at 6 p.m. The artist will be building an art installation inspired by New Orleans and with found objects in the city.

De La Puente is a Mexican artist and industrial designer with a master's degree in shipbuilding. In her work, she addresses the notions of time, space and memory combining conceptualism with multimedia. She has been actively working and collaborating with scientists from the National Institute of Astronomy in Mexico where she is developing new work. Her most recent exhibition and installation was developed in Mexico City and Russia, " La Gravedad de los Asuntos" was presented in Moscow, Russia, Slovenia and Mexico City.

article_summary:
Before the Affordable Care Act, more than 1 in 3 Latinas had no health insurance at all, and millions of others struggled with overpriced coverage and inadequate care.
Thanks to the gains of the ACA, more Latinas than ever have access to quality, affordable care, and we will not stop until that promise is fulfilled.
This decision preserves the financial assistance that has helped more than six million individuals purchase insurance plans through Obamacare's federally-run marketplaces, effectively maintaining affordable access to health care.
Food, beverages and music as well as children activities and free community services (legal, health, immigration, insurance and banking) will be featured.
The artist will be building an art installation inspired by New Orleans and with found objects in the city.
